title: 我哋必須保護香港民族嘅存亡同香港人嘅未來

replies.msg:
香港人實在太美麗
失去咗實在可惜








相比下
中國人實在太醜陋
若香港人被成功取代，實在太可悲










作爲香港人， 我哋必須保護香港民族嘅存亡同香港人嘅未來，因爲呢個係我哋作爲香港人與生俱來嘅職責。
我都唔明點解大陸人啲五官可以生到咁

quote.msg: 我都唔明點解大陸人啲五官可以生到咁

replies.msg: 北佬係咁

中共擁有香港統治權
部份香港人認為自己係中國人
究竟要點做?用咩方法?我地要守護既係咩?
先點可以要支那人同中共付出代價?
我會努力

華人係種族
中国人係某國嘅人/身份認同

中国人就成日問香港人/ 海外華人 "are you Chinese?"，其實暗地裡將華人等同中国人

replies.msg:
其實好簡單咁話the usage of the term "Chinese" is intentionally muddled by PRC for its political purposes就得
再講落去：
The PRC and its supporters intentionally use the same word(s) when referring to the legal nationality, the national identity, the race, and the ethnicity, as in:
"Chinese" as in your passport has either "PRC" or "ROC" printed on it, thus conferring a legal nationality that is "Chinese": 中國人
"Chinese" as in you identify yourself nationally as part of the descendants of the previous dynasties that operated within the region of modern day PRC: 中國人/漢人
"Chinese" as in the 19th century idea of a race, a group of people sharing a common set of things originating from a certain geographic location: 中國人/華人/中華民族
"Chinese" as in your phenotypes and biological descent conforms to a set of ethnic ideals: 中國人/漢人

And as if the above is not confusing enough, the official line is such that these terms are largely interchangeable whenever a PRC supporter argues on the issue of "Hong Konger" identity, or indeed anything to do with the question of "what is a Chinese".

Thus we have the oft heard line of illogic where a 3rd or even 4th generation immigrant to the US, whose parents and grandparents intermarried with various ethnicities, and yet because this person's great-great-great-great-grandfather once lived as a subject under the Qing Dynasty, it thus follows that the Chinese blood flows in this person's veins, and he is now obliged to call himself a "Chinese" above all else, that his culture must be that of this "China" (which he must stress "has existed for thousands of years, unchanged"), and his political allegiance must be towards the current dynasty/government/regime that rules this "China".

The situation gets even worse when you consider how the ethnicity of "Han" (again, interchangeably called either 漢人 or 中國人) is actually a mishmash of different ethnicities, with distinct languages, cultural customs, physical features, and centuries of lineage distance due to natural geographical boundaries (mountains and such) that discouraged movement and thus ethnic intermingling.

The above, of course, is seldom laid out as thus, and is usually simply delivered by calling the person "a Chinese, a 中國人". If you know you are not a "Chinese", then it is your responsibility to use the word very carefully, lest you pay host to a nefarious game of imperialistic propaganda.

replies.msg:
第三段個analogy可以咁繼續：
Imagine an ethnic Englishman, a certain but identifiable mix of Anglo-Saxon, Picts, Jutes, and Romans, who in now an Australian because his ancestors moved there, and because he has an Australian passport, and because he identifies as one and he behaves as one.

What the PRC and its supporters do is that they would claim this man is actually an American, and that he should follow the laws and orders of the current American government, because one certain great-great-great-great-grandfather of this man emigrated to the US, which fought against the UK rule in the Americas and won, establishing a new dynasty... I mean, a new nation, the United States. By the PRC's use of the term "Chinese", this Australian is now an "American", and if be disagrees, he'll face the dire consequences of political apostasy.

replies.msg:
連登嘅standard唔洗citation，字眼學術少少，有文有理，講到年份出處，已經係連登嘅學術standard
仲要係英文，無敵啦

btw 你介唔介意我加備註？

中國人/漢人 *
中國人/華人/中華民族 *

中國人【pronunciation: Zhōngguó Ren; Literally: People from "PRC"】
漢人【pronunciation: Hon Yan/ Hànrén; literally: 'Hon/Han people'】
華人【pronunciation: Wa Yan/ Huárén; literally: 'Wa/ Huá people'】
中華【pronunciation: Chung Wa/ zhōnghuá, literally: "the central Wa/Hua"】
民族 (race group)
